item.title: Ticket #1312 (plugin activate should use buttons) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
As the User referred to above, I have some input also. After realizing my "interpretation" error, I have gone back and examined the "Plugin Management" screen in an effort to determine what about it caused me to mis-read it so many times...

While I'm not exactly sure why, unless I'm careful, I still tend to interpret the plugin states as exactly opposite their true state. In thinking about it, I think I tend to scan the screen "horizontally". That is, I look at a plugin and then expect the final column to tell me it's *CURRENT* state - not what I can change it's state to. Obviously, if I slow down enough to really analyze the screen, it's intent makes sense, but it somehow seems backwards to me at a casual glance.

For example:

When I look quickly at a plugin that may read like this:

My Plugin | 1.0 | The Author | The Description | Activate

I tend to see that plugin as "Active". Again, I expect that last column to tell me it's *current* state, so somehow my brain is reading the final term as "Active". To me, the above line is very counter-intuitive to the actual meaning.

Here are a few alternatives to that layout that might tend to avoid this casual mis-interpretation:

  1. Change the values in the last column to "Yes" or "No", and the header to "Active". At least this way, if you aren't familiar withe screen layout, you have to read the column header to determine what the "Yes" and "No" refer to. Once you are familiar with the screen, "Yes" and "No" tend to convey the proper meaning upon a "horizontal only" glance at a plugin.
  1. Change to values to "On" and "Off" and the header to "Current State"

Bottom line, I think for useability, the term needs to indicate the plugin's *current* state in an unambiguous manner.

Thanks,

Jeff Godfrey

item.title: Ticket #1312 (plugin activate should use buttons) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1312 (plugin activate should use buttons) created
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
I've a user who had problems with a plugin of mine. I eventually discovered the plugin was not activated, despite the fact he was consistently telling him that it was.

Fact is, he read the 'Activate' button as 'Activated' status, as in 'Selected theme'. I'm aware WP 1.5.1 highlights the active plugins in green. But based on this user, I suggest it is not enough. I suggest the following:

  • Make the buttons in the plugin selector look like buttons (input type="button"...)

And to ensure the display is consistent:

  • Make the buttons in the theme selector look like buttons as well

item.title: Ticket #1275 (RSS reports 304 Not Modified even if they have changed.) updated
item.dc:creator: dougal
item.description:
This logic still isn't complete. It only handles the case where both the If-Modified-Since *and* the If-None-Match (ETag) headers are present. But the spec allows for a case where only one (either one) of the headers is present.

If only one of them is present, then it must satisfy its condition in order to return a 304: either If-Modified-Since is >= the web content's modify date, OR the If-None-Match is equal to what the server thinks the ETag should be.

If both are present, then both conditions must be true (which is all we're checking right now).

We need to put back in support for the case where only one of the headers are present, or we'll be missing some 304 opportunities, and wasting bandwidth.

edited on: 05-05-05 13:52

edited on: 05-05-05 13:52

item.title: Ticket #1311 (WP caches to much information) updated
item.dc:creator: Syn
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1311 (WP caches to much information) created
item.dc:creator: Syn
item.description:
It is depressive, how WordPress caches the Blog. Adding topics and comments is no problem, but as Admin, even i am logged in, WordPress shows always Registration and not the SiteAdmin link. I am on 1.5 and refreshing browser does not help. Only klicking onto the Blogsname at the header. Same with changing theme-pictures, none of the users see it.

What could be the matter? I wont set the whole thing to no-cache, it would bust the traffic (someday) and it is quite a torture for low bandwidth users.

Im on Firefox 1.0.3, have no caching plugins nor any plugins to generate static pages, The WP is running onto a PHP 5 Server.

Minor plugins, mail obfuscator and a selfwritten small 'last commentor' viewer. The problem occur while deactivating them too

item.title: Ticket #1296 (New registered users have 'not-deletable' http:/// URL als Homepage) updated
item.dc:creator: Syn
item.description:
This is not a bug, the comments DB saves every user entry for every single comment. As you can see it in the wp_comments table. The cause is that you can usually write a comment as a non registered user, so those users occur only one time and the WP writes everytime a static entry of your mail and URL and so on. For registered users it would be better to make a refrence to their details, but WP does not distinguish between them. I guess we have to live with that. There are other problems here

edited on: 05-05-05 10:14

item.title: Ticket #1310 (RSS enclosures) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1310 (RSS enclosures) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
This was closed out previously, but is still in error.

According to the RSS 2.0 folk, whether it is badly documented or not in the spec, only one enclosure is allowed. Using more than one results in an invalid feed error from the RSS validator, and may cause breaks in aggregators.

item.title: Ticket #1309 (Incorrect enclosures for Atom feeds) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1309 (Incorrect enclosures for Atom feeds) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Following through on the Atom specification change of enclosures to links, I've created a second function, atom_enclosure, which creates Atom enclosures per the spec.

I've submitted a request to the RSS Validator folks to upgrade the validator to handle Atom enclosures properly.

item.title: Ticket #1308 (2nd occurrence of list_cats finds no categories) updated
item.dc:creator: jrabbe
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1308 (2nd occurrence of list_cats finds no categories) created
item.dc:creator: jrabbe
item.description: If list_cats is called twice from the same template, the second call will return "no categories". Has been reproduced using two instances of wp_list_cats (and thereby list_cats) with the default arguments, as well as most other combinations of list_cats and wp_list_cats with different arguments.

item.title: Ticket #977 (the loop should clean up after itself) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: Would it make more sense to isolate the WP query entirely? That would enable a you to create and use several loops at once, in very much the same way as you would create several datasets in an asp.NET application.

item.title: Ticket #1307 (wp-admin/admin.php crash) created
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
the wp-amazon plugin makes the thing crash.

to solve, replace line 2 of wp-admin/admin.php: require_once('../wp-config.php');

with: require_once(ABSPATH . 'wp-config.php');

item.title: Ticket #1306 (Dict lookup regex too restrictive) updated
item.dc:creator: h3h
item.description: The first patch has an extra parenthesis in it. Use rev2.

item.title: Ticket #1306 (Dict lookup regex too restrictive) updated
item.dc:creator: h3h
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1306 (Dict lookup regex too restrictive) created
item.dc:creator: h3h
item.description:
On the Write Post screen, one can click the "Dict." button to get a dictionary definition for a selected word or the user will be prompted for a word to get a definition for. If the user presses Cancel in the dialog asking for a word, a new window proceeds to open to answers.com with the world "null".

I've made a simple modification that checks for a null return value from the prompt() function, in addition to a simple regex test that ensures the world is at least one word-character long.

item.title: Ticket #1181 (comment posting leads to blank page) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
I've a user who is getting a blank page as well. I'm redirecting him to here, in case this helps.

He mentions the following:

Warning: call_user_func_array(): First argumented is expected to be a valid callback, 'Markdown' was given in /usr/local/apache/htdocs/wp- includes/functions.php on line 893

I'm completely unable to reproduce so I presume this is some kind of spam code problem rather than a Markdown problem.
